Owners of at least 75 percent of the property within the proposed district must sign the petition for the petition to be presented to the city council. If the proposed special tax district encompasses more than one subdivision as shown by plats filed in the public land records of the county, owners of 75 percent of the property within the special tax district in each and all of the included subdivisions must sign the petition. Unless owners of 100 percent of the property have signed the petition, a public hearing shall be held by the city council after having advertised one time in the official legal organ of the county, and a sign shall be posted in the proposed special tax district giving notice of the hearing at least ten days before the public hearing. (b) The petition for the creation of the proposed special tax district must be returned to the city administrator within 90 days of the presentment of the request. The applicant shall utilize Form No. 4-8-2013 on file with the city administrator. The city administrator shall verify the signatures on the petition and that the requisite number of property owners has signed said petition. Said petition must be accompanied by a certificate of title or other document that shows the public's interest in the right-of-way of a road or easements for construction and maintenance of infrastructure or a necessary letter of commitment from the owner to convey the road or necessary easements to the city any payment pursuant to this Code. (c) By signing the petition for the creation of a new special tax district, all petitioners within a proposed special tax district shall be deemed to have actual or constructive notice of this article and all the provisions contained herein, as well as the request and petition for a special tax district. (d) All successors in interest to the property owners within a certain district at the time of the creation of said special tax district shall be deemed to have constructive notice of this article and the existing special tax district or request wherein the property is located due to the existence of public records containing such information. (e) Upon receipt of a petition as provided herein and after a public hearing, if one is required, the city council shall take under consideration the establishment of the requested special tax district. The city council, in its sole discretion, may vote to create one or more of such districts based upon all of the evidence presented to the city council. Nothing contained herein shall create any right by any property owner to the creation of such districts. The creation of one or more of such districts shall not generate a precedent or obligation on the city council to approve future requests for a special tax district; rather, each proposed district shall be considered based on the totality of the evidence regarding each respective district. The decision of the city council, in the exercise of their discretion, shall be final. (f) The decision of the city council to create special tax districts shall be evidenced by resolutions adopted at a regular or special meeting of the city council. (g) At the time of petition, no parcels in a proposed special tax district may be exempt or owned by entities entitled to a real property tax exemption. If after the establishment of a special tax district the greater of 50 acres or ten percent of the total acreage of the district shall become exempt, the special tax district shall be dissolved. In making this determination, the areas of roads, sidewalks, trailways, utility easements, and parcels on which there are water or wastewater treatment or municipal facilities owned by the city shall not be considered. (h) Any special tax district established hereunder shall be dissolved 20 years from the date established. (i) The taxes levied in any special tax district shall not exceed an additional three mills above the millage rate levied on properties outside of the district and not within any other special tax district. (j) No property may be included in a special tax district if property taxes are outstanding or on which any tax liens exist. (k) Additional property may be added to an existing special tax district under the same process and requirement for creation of the special tax district. (Ord. of 4-8-2013, § 41-108) Sec. 42-185. - Payments. The resolution adopted by the city council establishing a special tax district may provide that beginning in the first, second or third year, and continuing for a period of 14 years, the city shall pay up to 75 percent of the ad valorem property taxes collected in the special tax district to allow recoupment of the cost of infrastructure dedicated to the city which lies within easements or rights-of-way dedicated to the city. In the petition, the petitioner shall set forth whether the recoupment period shall begin in the first, second or third year. The petitioner or his successors in interest shall certify to the city in writing under oath, the cost of such infrastructure and the fact of dedication. So long as costs of dedicated infrastructure remain unreimbursed, the petitioner or his successors may seek recoupment during the entire 14-year period. The petitioner shall submit his recoupment application on a form provided by the city. The remaining funds collected shall be used for infrastructure or services provided by the city in the area of the special tax district. (Ord. of 4-8-2013, § 41-109) Sec. 42-186. - Federal, state laws to prevail. If any provision of this article is in conflict with any state or federal law, or with any rule, regulation, or any order of any agency of the state or federal agency having jurisdiction of the subject matter of this article, it is hereby deemed to the intention of the city council that the state or federal law or rule, regulation, or order shall prevail such that the remaining portion of this article shall be deemed to be of full force or effect. (Ord. of 4-8-2013, § 41-110)

div.head: Chapter 44 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 44-1—44-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TRAFFIC CONTROL[1]
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Cities are authorized to exercise power over parking facilities and traffic control devices, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4), (11); power of local authorities with respect to uniform rules of the road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-370 et seq.; traffic generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 et seq.; uniform rules of the road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; uniform rules of the road by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372; jurisdiction of municipal courts over misdemeanor traffic offenses, O.C.G.A. § 40-14-21(a).
Sec. 44-19. - Uniform Rules of the Road adopted. (a) Adoption by reference. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-372 through 40-6-376, the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-1 to 40-6-395 (except for §§ 40-6-393 and 40-6-394), known as the Uniform Rules of the Road, and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. §§ 40-1-1 and 40-2-20 and O.C.G.A. § 40-5-20 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the city with like effect as if recited herein. (b) Penalties. Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be punished by a fine according to the penalties described in the general provisions chapter. (c) Suspended or revoked licenses. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-5-121, the municipal court shall be authorized to impose punishment in accordance with state law for convictions of driving while a license is suspended or revoked. (d) Speed limits. The city shall, from time to time, adopt by ordinance a list of roads and speed limits to be maintained by the city administrator.
